name: Killing Floor 2

reviews.review_text: Killing Floor 1 was like a chocolate chip cookie.  Simple, enjoyable, and there was no end to how much you could enjoy it.  Killing Floor 2 is like 2 chocolate chip cookies.  There's more of it to enjoy.

Now that Killing Floor 2 is FINALLY out, I can now finally say with absolute certainty, there are 5 things wrong with this game right off the bat.  1. Survivalist Class. What the hell is this? People could play how they wanted to before, are you shoehorning them into one class now? What can people do as their classes now? Are they not allowed to purchase any other weapon except their own class's designated weapon?  2. Another one of those games that is boring as hell to play alone and I can definitely say with all perks at 25, I hate this game solo.  3. The Versus mode is imbalanced and always will be. The ZEDs, no matter what you do to them, will always crush the other team because of the Bloats who can place mines everywhere, creating a camping problem and Gorefasts are force spawned on players way too frequently.   4. They replaced the datamined Martial Artist class for the Survivalist class. Why? The Berzerker could be based around attack speed and/or damage depending on your playstyle. Even using the parry ability to increase your attack speed or movement or what not. Don't make the Berzerker a tanky class like Martial Artist was meant to be. The Katana does not suit the Berzerker's style of play. It's very based on finesse and precision. Berzerker is not precise. End of.  5. Their communication with the fans/customers when they were doing this game was TERRIBLE. You expect them to actually fix stuff and/or listen to their customers to make the game better? No. What do they desire? Releasing the market on Early Access customers to see how much money they can milk on an idea that could have been stripped away in an instant, running away with the money. Do you desire to help a developer with risks like that? I wouldn't. I regret it too as I was thinking they were updating the gfx from KF1 and expanding on the idea, not... this...  4 things I like about the game.  1. It's fun being the Gunslinger, Berzerker, SWAT and Support classes. Dual wielding, meleeing up close, using the Kriss smg and shotgunning your way to victory is very satisfying.  2. Being a Scrake, Stalker, Husk and a Fleshpound is SO rewarding in versus. I would definitely recommend it.  3. Hate grinding? Want to experience the game at full potential? Go to perk training servers. You can soon see what the game is like without the long, strenuous grind on the same 3 maps that people play. It's like Counter Strike all over again with de_dust. It's not balanced or anything in terms of layout for versus, it's just because of people liking all the MLG garbage that comes from those maps. Why is this in the positive section? Well it's the positive. You can farm this annoying grind away, because let me tell you. The grind is irritable.  Do NOT get this game if you play a lot of games solo like me. They chose to release the market while it was still in early access. If you trust a shifty company like that that doesn't communicate with their customers properly, give this one a definite skip to tell them that you won't stand for shady practices.  DO NOT GET GAMES IN EARLY ACCESS! This is the first and last time I rely on a sequel of a good game to be just as good as the first. ALWAYS be paranoid everyone. Let them cater to YOU! You hold money. They don't, unless you give it to 'em. You have the power to make them better, you also have the power to make them worse.  Don't get this game.

Killing Floor 2 is a sequel to the popular and successful Killing Floor 1. Keep in mind that Killing Floor 2 is in early access and has yet to receive a full release. Many players from the previous title may know that some of the new features of Killing Floor 2 included sprinting and crosshair, which may come as a disappointment. While I personally do not believe this should be an issue at all for both veteran and new players, it does remove the aspect of having your knife out to run quicker.  About the  graphics  - there is no doubt that there is a big improvement. The game has updated graphics and textures which look significantly better than they did before.   There are 10  waves  and on the 11th wave you have to fight against a boss (either the Patriarch or Hans Volter for now). By the end of your tenth wave the map you’re surviving appears splattered in blood from each shot you make. It’s a good feature and definitely adds atmosphere to the chaos.   The first Killing Floor provided a selection of 7  perks . Killing Floor 2’s Early Access contains 9 perks for now - Berserker, Commando, Support, Field Medic, Demolitionist, Sharpshooter, Firebug, Gunslinger and the new perk Swat. Once the game reaches its full release it is rumoured that it will include 10 perks in total. Each perk has its own special skill which is unlocked at levels 5,10,15,20 and 25 and there are two options of which you can't choose your special skill.   The specimens  in Killing Floor 2 are a bit modified compared to Killing Floor 1. There are not many combos you can use for the insta - kill of the big zeds. I have seen one for the medic with his nades and I can't even call it a combo, more like a simple strategy and one for the firebug. So it is not very easy to kill Fleshpounds and Scrakes. The one thing I don't like is that if someone enrages the Scrake or the Fleshpound, they can attack anyone they want. So I find it really annoying to have them charging against me, without being prepared to kill them. Headshots here are essential, so try your best not to miss them.  I have a mixed feeling when it comes to  teamplay  . When the waves get harder in some of the cases everybody just runs around trying to save theirselves and it would be pure luck if you end the wave with your teammates being around you, because in some situations it is impossible to stay together. So it is best to count on yourself to finish the wave, alive.   There are not many  guns  added to this game, but hopefully new ones will be released soon.  More maps, weapons, game modes, removing classes imbalance, fixing teleporting zeds and concentrating on the game's development rather than adding cosmetics will definitely make more Killing Floor 2 players happy.   Overall I would not recommend this game to other people for now, because Tripwire have turned it into a casual game. You play 1-2 maps and everything is okay, but after that it gets deadly boring ... If I have to compare it with KF1 - a BIG lack of content. Sure it is an early access, but there aren't any signs of progress.  In the end after playing around 400 hours I came to the following conslusion: Killing Floor 2 - a game where disscussing other player's performance it is more important than the game itself. Enjoy.

I enjoyed Killing Floor 1 quite a bit, and thus picked up KF2 fairly early in the Early Access process.  However, when a game studio clearly has a hard time creating and implementing new content, the decision to add PvP and microtransactions in lieu of improving the core gameplay loop is extremely dubious.

I'll keep this as unbiased as possible.  Killing Floor 2 is the successful sequel to Killing Floor 1. The ZEDs are much scarier then their KF1 counter parts (and the Clot now has a sick as ♥♥♥♥ swag walk), the guns feel powerful and do some real damage thanks to the new M.E.A.T. system which allows you dig into the brains of a Fleshpounds with an AK12 and the characters all have unique voices now which, personally from my perspective, is a great thing because it opens up much wider varieties of humour then just 'WAAAANKARS!'.  However, development for the game is slow and while Tripwire are doing their best to make the perks feel strong and balanced while also preventing Fleshpounds from being nearly undestroyable there is one very obvious and glaring flaw for now.   Microtransactions in an unfinished game   Now I dunno why this even got past the suggestion phase, the game isn't complete, there are unfinished balancing issues to be addressed, gunslinger is still to be added to the game and work on Sharpshooter (which I'm interested in due to the fast paced nature of Killing Floor 2) is almost non-existant. Not only are we missing one of our core vanilla perks from Killing Floor 1 but the game is nowhere near finished in terms of balancing and perk weapons.  Now, this wouldn't be an issue if the game was finished and these items were offered in a DLC pack, these items are simply cosmetic and weapon skins that do not affect gameplay in any form but the reason this is such a bad thing is because it's preventing production and work  on things that need to be addressed in the game right now!   I listed this as negative purely because of how strong an impact microtransactions have on the gaming industry right now, microtransactions should  NOT  be a part of any game that you pay full price for, it's a gimmick for free-to-play games. Not paid products like Killing Floor 2 which is actually  far from finished.   I would love to make this a positive review and I had planned on writing a positive review for Killing Floor 2 but the fact they are also attempting to censor any form of backlash about their decision on the Tripwire Interactive forums has changed my mind. I will not say don't buy this game but I will say this with a heavy heart.   Buy with caution.

What the hell happened, Tripwire?  As a long time KF1 player, this game was so promising in the beginning, the gameplay was solid, the combat was hectic and satisfying, the guns were nothing short of amazing (Did they ever fix reloading both guns after firing a single shot with akimbo pistols? Literally the only complaint I can come up with). The graphics were equally impressive. And then it all fell apart.  Updates were slow. Fine, game development isn't an easy task, and is time-consuming to say the least, particularly when you're aiming to release a product at its best.  Then the microtransactions came. A system intended to maximize profit for literally zero effort beyond the initial implementation, and extremely minimal effort should they decide to actually add new 'content' to the system. For one thing, the timing couldn't have been worse with another well-known game screwing over their players by doing the exact same thing weeks prior. They still haven't fully recovered from that, and probably never will even with all of their damage control and making their crates free to open (though I'm fairly certain the trader crowd has happily moved in to replace the players they lost - ensuring the already terrible community will never recover).  I'll admit I was intrigued by the concept, but felt it would be out of place and would waste time and money to implement it... I am of course talking about the PvP mode. PvP was a mode that 'everybody' apparently wanted. I have no idea who 'everybody' is as I have not met or seen them yet. I suspect they're currently silver ranked in ('competitive' game here) and are playing that instead. I'm assuming it died about a month after release on account of being boring, repetitive and horribly unbalanced. I myself played it for about a day.  Oh and let's not forget the (Rushed? I don't know, but it literally brings nothing new to the game whatsoever) new perk. Because we weren't insulted enough with the delays, unwanted 'content' updates and questionable business practices already, right?  I want to like this game. At some point in time I did. Somewhere underneath it all there actually is a truly great game trying to break free of the things holding it down. Unfortunately it can't, and never will.

More action, more perks, more gore, more dosh, better visuals, better animation, even better gunplay and no annoying hitboxes - a good example of the sequel that sticks to the old winning formula and adds some spice without trying to fix anything that was not broken

It's finally out, and surprisingly it didn't take the second Ice Age for that to happen. Good on you, Tripwire. So for this grand occasion I can finally update my review for what has changed and what hasn't. Is this fully released version now worth getting?  PROS: +Updated Graphics, and kudos on making the Skrake look more menacing +More Gore, makes it look like those over-the-top games people play inside games or TV shows. This is a good thing. +More Music, always a nice touch. +More perks (Though the Survivalist perk kinda makes all the others seem redundant, but that's just me)  NEGATIVES: -So you promised more zeds? I don't see any, unless you're talking about the two clot varients and Hans, which besides Hans is absolutly abyssmal. -You cannot host a server for friends in-game. Instead, you have to go OUTSIDE OF THE GAME and download+fiddle around with a program. How the hell do you mess up something that was in KF1? -Microtransactions, and on top of that CS:GO-style microtransactions. I don't need elaborate on why this is a bad thing. -New Fleshpound. Bigger isn't always better guys, now he just looks like a doofy weight-lifter with a blender on his hands. -Small, claustrophobic maps. Now, these are a good thing regularly, especially with a game like this. However, WHEN YOU HAVE _JUST_ SMALL MAPS IT'S A PROBLEM. -Design. Where did the grittiness from KF1 go? Ain't here, that's for sure. No-sir-ee-bob, just Future and metal. Weeeee. -New PvP gamemode. Why? Now you have to balance a game that is abotu PvE around it's PvP element. Where's the fun in that? (Although A for effort in trying to add a new game-mode) -Hey, remember how Bloats and Sirens were annoying but manageable in KF1? Those were the days, huh? Now Bloats are bullet-sponges and Sirens pack metal armor that just ping off your shots. So do Fleshpounds, but I'm giving them a pass for that making them more threatening than annoying like the other two. -KF2 has no charm. The only reason I remember KF2 is because it's the sequel to KF1 and that it's what taught me never to buy Early-Access games.  TL;DR: KF2 is inferior to KF1. Don't waste your money on this, buy KF1 instead.

Now having reached 400 hours in this game I would like to update my review.   Killing Floor 2 is a co-op shooter that requires communication and teamwork in order to get the job done. There are different wave systems, there is the short game which is only 4 waves, the medium which is 7 waves, and the long game which is 10 waves. There is also versus which allows you to play as the experiments rather than humans.  The Classes are as follows Berzerker(Melee) Commando(Assault Rifles) Support(Shotguns) Field Medic(Healing weapons) Demolitionist(Explosives) Firebug(Fire c:) Gunslinger(Dual Pistols) Sharpshooter(Rifles) Survivalist(Everything but not good at everything but not terrible at everything, but almost terrible cause they always die) Swat(Sub Machine Guns)   Overall since i've purched the game it has come very far. First starting it only had 4 perks and each of them were buggy and some of the things didn't even work. Now everything is fluid and well made. A lot of time has been invested in this game over its course from E.A. to full release a couple of months ago. Also I will dare to say that this is an improvement on the first Killing Floor. Sure it lacks the amount of maps and weapons but from what we've been told there is more to come from tripwire.   Now I am going to get into what I really like about this game.  -Classes: It's pretty useful because if you want to kill large zeds you are not just confined to a single class that can kill them, there are several different classes that can kill big zeds with ease, and several that can kill the small zeds also.  -Weapons: Now even though there may not be that many each weapon feels unique with its use, some are stronger than others while some shoot faster. Each one is used by a class (Unless you're playing surivalist) and while using them you can see how powerful the weapons can really be as you level up.  -Characters/Cosmetics: Now I know what you're saying 'MICROTRANSACTIONS??? COSMETICS??? NNNRRRAAAAAAHHHH' Calm down. These cosmetics in the game allows you to really show your personality with how many you can put on, whether you wanna look silly or completely serious they've got that handled for you, emotes will be added soon after the beta is over so we have to look forward to that too.   The characters are relatable to about any kind of person, whether you wanna be a french metal girl to a silly dutch dj that takes nothing seriously.   Now I said microtransations earlier, let me explain that. There are crate drops, drops happen about once every 24 hours, it can be a skin for your weapons, a cosmetic or even a crate. How you open these crates is the 'transaction' part. There are keys you can purchase for about $2.49 and they allow you to receive a random item that is listed in the crate. Personally I have found this to be quite lucrative as i've gotten plenty of rares and sold them for LOADSAMONEY.   -Maps: Theres only about 13 different maps to choose from, (12 if you don't include Zed landing because its in beta) Each map has a couple different areas where you can hold out for the entire game. Some spots are harder than others and some just make it too easy especially with a good team.  -Zed Variation: Whether you call them Zeds or Experiments, they've added a couple different Zeds to the mix. The standard lineup is from weakest to strongest, this is also taken from the current beta the game has, the enemies in brackets are enemies that are only in the beta, except for the Blue Alpha Clot, he is in both beta and base game but in the beta he is much stronger.   It goes: Cyst, Crawler, White Crawler, Alpha Clot, Slasher, Gorefast, Stalker, [Alpha Clot] Bloat, Siren, [GoreFiend] Husk, Scrake, Fleshpound, Dr. Hans Volter, and The Patriarch.  Not only do the enemies get progressively harder as you go up in difficulty ratings, but as more players join the match more spawn and they gain even more health and do more damage.  Now sadly I will have to tell you about the things I don't like about this game.  -Cop outs: What I really mean by this is my complete opinion and is not fact as of right now. There are two things that have been brought the the game, The survivalist perk which at its core is mediocre at everything instead of being an expect like the other classes, Instead of a new and different playstyle, T.W.I. has encouraged people to continue the trend of not using perk weapons with your perk and people getting upset as to why they aren't leveling up.   Another thing is the multi perk weapon system they've added in the beta. Allowing other classes to use more weapons is fun and all but its not fun when things become broken and exploits are easily accessable and to use. Such as the Commando's ability to use the Field Medic's Assault rifle. The rifle with the Commando has little to no recoil and the damage is off the charts. Able to decap a Scrake in half a magazine on Hell on Earth isn't what I consider fun, it somewhat ruins the difficulty of the game.  -Difficulty Jump: Understandably I love the current difficulties but for the masses the jump from hard to suicidal can be too much. Normal is really calm and if you're looking to just feel like an 80's action movie where you're practically godlike and you can rip your enemies heads off then thats your difficulty. If you wanna feel helpless then play Hell on Earth. Suicidal adds different animations then what you would see in Normal and Hard, not to mention there is much more health and damaged added.   I mean honestly there isn't that much I don't like about the game besides some of its players. But you get that with every game.  Overall if you like working in a team, like gore, oh man theres lots of gore. Having a unique playstyle and mastering a class then this game is for you.

I bought a copy of Killing Floor 2 from Steam while it was still in Early Access. It was fun, at first. A garden variety bot safari with multiple playable classes and a decent few levels. But during what was supposed to have been a content update, Tripwire Interactive (the developers) decided they wanted everyone who played their game to host their microtransaction store. So they installed one on all of our computers without prior warning, without and opt-out, and after we'd paid full price. 1- Tripwire Interactive do not, have never, and will never have my permission to operate a branch of thier business on my private property. 2- My computer is my private property. Neither of these positions (labelled 1- and 2-) are in any way negotiable. I had been given plenty of reasons, from photographs to videos to firsthand experience, to believe that this game did not and would not involve microtransactions of any variety. **To this day (November 21st, 2016) we paying customers have had only two options - continue to play the game with the microtransaction store in place, or uninstall and remove a game we had already paid for. Many of us, myself included, have already spent far too many hours with the game to qualify for a refund under Valve's refund policy. This is absolutely not acceptable.** Under no circumstances would I advise anyone to buy a copy of Killing Floor 2, or any of the other games made by Tripwire Interactive.  **Edit: It is now (11/23/16) possible to get a refund if you've played Killing Floor 2 for very little or no time after its official release date. I've completed the refund process and confirm that, for at least the time being, a refund is available to those qualified. And so I withdraw my complaint about the lack of fair remedy.

My very first review of a Steam game, so please forgive me if i forgot to mention something. Also this is a pretty long review so ignore it if you dont like reading too much. Here are my Pros and Cons:  Pros: -Insanely fun and addictive gameplay. -Zed Time (short slow motion period), makes the game so much better when you see all that gore in its splendour. -Different perks with different guns allowing you to have an overall team that can fill the weaknesses of each individual perk with the strengths of another. -Zeds getting gradually stronger every wave, allowing you to get powerful items to fight them, climaxing in a boss battle worth your time and money. -2 Bosses, each with individual strenghts and weaknesses that require a lot of teamplay and tactical preparation to defeat. -25 levels on each perk, with 2 options to improve your current perk being unlocked every 5 levels. -Being able to switch from one perk to another and configure your perks skills between waves, so that you dont start crying when someone from your team has to leave and ruins your team comp. -Good music that will put you in the mood for some brutal action. -Carefully designed official and community maps offering unique opportunities. -Different difficulties for new players to get the hang of the game and for hardcore veterans to satisfy their thirst for blood and dismemberment. -Different types of Zeds, each with different skills, strengths and weaknesses. -Many characters to choose from, each with his/her own jokes, remarks and battlecries. They can also be customised from top to bottom. -Active developer team and community, offering a variety of new content to keep you interested. -Fun boss and player character chatter, making this game less horror and more fun. -On higher difficulties some zeds have special attacks and powers, making the game much more challanging and volatile. -Great AI, very flexible, the zeds often try to outnumber you or sneak up behind and make your job harder, and they also try to find weaknesses in your position or comp and take advantage of them, sometimes succeeding and exterminating your team. -You can browse community servers or just let the game search for a server automatically based on your preferences. Also works while in a lobby.  Cons: -After a while it becomes repetitive. -Not as many guns in the game for now (i think 5-6 for each perk), adding to the repetitiveness until it becomes sort of a norm or monotony. -Leveling up your perks takes a while, and it may be rewarding at the end when you get to enjoy them but until then you're stuck killing on community made perk training maps or normal ones. -Some perks are unbalanced.  As you can see this game has a lot of good and a little bad, which can be improved and most likely will. Overall a great game. If you took the time reading this you should definitely buy it right now,

Killing Floor 2 is a great gore-fest action shooter that got me hooked for quite a few hours so far. What really shines is the amazing soundtrack that helps Zed-killing just that more badass than it already is. The classes each differ from the rest and really spawns the question, 'should i hack and disembowel my enemies with a Katana or should i just blow them to pieces with an AA12?'. The only cons that are worth pointing out is the boss battle varieties (there's only 2) but they could be fixed with future updates. Despite what a lot of the negative reviewers are saying, This game is still highly worth it for it's current pricetag, When it started in Early Access it was and will remain to be the most polished Early Access game I've ever played.   Literally all it was missing when it started was content, and they've added a good bit since then, It still needs more, but they're already planning on it, just like they did with KF1, That game got a ton of content updates over the years, so there's no real need worry that they won't do the same here aswell.   And I think a lot of the consumers here don't realize just how long a game takes to make, I ended up buying the game as soon as it came out in Early Access, and though it was very polished it was lacking content at the time, but I was completely willing to wait, And it's not like you wouldn't have other games to distract you and pass time while it gets worked on. Games take years to make, just because the Devs let us all enjoy a polished Early Access doesn't mean there wasn't problems we didn't see or gamebreaking bugs that could have been holding back development  The Devs spent thousands of hours of their lives to give us a sequel to a game we loved and it delivered in my opinion, It was a labor of love for them, so give them a break and enjoy the free content updates we're going to be getting who knows how many years into the future

So a few years ago, my friends told me to purchase a little game called Killing Floor. I had an absolute blast with it, from the characters cheesy dialouge, the variaty of zeds, and the huge arsenal and number of classes. The game was definelty work every penny. A few months of KF, I see in one of the in game adds that Tripwire was working on a Killing Floor 2. Needless to say I got really excited. A bit later the early access version came to Steam, and I instantly purchased it. Even with the little content that they had, which was to be expected since it just came out of alpha, I still had a blast with it. I saw this game grow with the constant updates that Tripwire released, Incenerate n' Detonate, Return of the Patriarch, Bulls-eye. and Tactical Response. And with the full release out, I can wholeheartedly say that if you ever had interest in buying this game, you should drop that money into this game and get it. TW still has pleanty of stuff to do with the game in terms of updates; more weapons, new zed, new boss, seasonal content (please bring back the hillbillies TW, that was great). 10 perks, each with 25 levels, 4 levels of difficulty, several official maps with many more community made maps, lots of fun guns to play with, you will be playing for a while. And if you're into costumizablity of characters, they've got that too with the Zed-conomy feature and daily game rewards, I just wish they would lower the price of keys to open chests and usbs, but oh well. Without a doubt, I can say this is probably my favorite game to play with my friends in my library atm, and I look forward for it to grow. Buy it.

A horde-style zombie survival game. I purchased this when it was in early access and was pretty dissapointed in the lack of conctent and slow development, but i think it was worth it in the end.   You have to survive a specific amount of waves depending on what game length you choose. You can do this solo with a reduced amount of zeds (zombies) or play co-op with up to 6 people online.  There are 10 perks to choose from, every one using different types of weapons and grenades. The most interesting ones are the firebug, who uses flamethrowers and incendiary weapons, the berserker, who uses sledgehammers and katanas, and the gunslinger, who dual wields pistols and revolvers. Apart from that there are many weapon types. Rifles, Smg's, rocket launchers, shotguns, sniper rifles, etc.  As you play with your chosen perk, you level up and gain bonuses. Bonuses include: increased perk weapon damage, health boosts, berserkers can gain back health with every kill, commandos can see enemies health bars, medics can increase their healing, and so on. Every perk is best at dealing with a specific type of zed, and you a balanced team if you want to win at the harder difficulties.   Killing Floor 2 feels very good to play, all the guns feel satisfying to use, the metal soundtrack is great with lots of licensed songs, and the visuals are impressive, and run without any hitches even on my older PC.   Killing Floor 2 also has visual customization in form of microtransactions. You have weapon skins, clothing and visual accessories for your character. These are completely cosmetic and dont affect your stats in any way, and you can get a free item every day, even rare ones that you can sell on the market.  Overall Killing Floor 2 is great, has lots of replay value, is very challenging and is a blast to play with good teammates.

When I would recruit friends to play the original Killing Floor with me, I would describe it as 'Left for Dead, but better.' It had the same engaging action, hilarious gore, and rewarding weapon mechanics, while adding a progression system and perks that allowed teammates to cater their play to their own style.  Killing Floor 2 ups the ante on all the features that made its predecessor great. There are more perks, a revamped XP system, and thanks to the new unlockable perk skills, there are more ways than ever to play KF. It's a beautiful experience all the way through, with visually stunning and meticulously detailed new maps, redesigned weapon animations, and a cutting-edge gibbing system. Each kill is more rewarding, but more difficult too: the zeds now have the ability to protect themselves and respond to your attacks.  By far the biggest con is that Killing Floor could run on a toaster plugged into a CRT television, but KF2 is much more demanding on your hardware, especially with all of Nvidia's built-in new high-end antialiasing and physics options turned on. Don't expect to be able to play this game on the computer your grandfather uses to look at pictures of warships.  Killing Floor 2 has become the new perfect game to play when you want to kill time with your friends, but don't have the energy to focus on a competitive shooter, like Counter Strike, and don't want to get bored to death playing Civ for seven straight hours. All you need is a system with some brawn and an insatiable desire to emancipate Zed organs from Zed bodies.

Killing floor 2 follows the same great tradition as the first game. Essentially, you play up to 10 rounds in an increasingly difficult wave-based arena over a series of maps ranging from simple to intermediate levels of complexity.   If you didn't hate that summary, read on.  What I love about this game is that there are very few griefers. In fact there are measures to allow a group of people to deal with that and bans get thrown around when people are being ♥♥♥♥♥.   In terms of game quality, it's first rate. The game looks great, it plays with a very solid frame rate, and it has very few bugs that I don't see people appreciate often enough. Play a game for long enough, you'll find bugs, trust me.  Balance. Can we talk Balance? Taking a lot of ideas from the first game, many of the same classes made their way back and the balance quality (I think) is very much still here. It's rare to find a game this well balanced. At the end of the day, whatever class you choose, you'll have to really bring it at the higher difficulties, and those high difficulties are required if you want to level your characters at a decent rate. (The higher difficulty levels give xp modifiers).  Enemies are designed with love and care and they crunch and explode satisfyingly.   What don't I like? After you level 2 or 3 characters, the game does begin to feel a bit repetitive. You'll need to take little breaks here and there to get it to feel fresh again. This isn't a knock on this particular game, all games feel repetitive after you grind for a while.  The potential here, of course, is to offer more game modes. At the moment there's just one: Survival. In the first killing floor they had mission based stuff, and I suspect those game modes are coming soon.  As a counter point to my negative critisism, you should know that TRIPWIRE have ALWAYs been very good at supporting their games and offering FREE updates twice or three times a year. If they continue in that vien, I know I'll be playing this for many years to come.

UPDATE: As of official game launch and Survivalist release: New enemy tactics such as blocking and evading, some have new abilities, and changes to behavior as well as player icons so you can see where teammates are as well as the last ~3 zeds of the wave so you can find out if it's despawning constantly or a teammate is kiting it around to troll the team. Team trolling is still out of control for some with the vote kick being abused on public servers.   It's faster paced than the previous title with a few tweaks to how zeds attack you. Pros: -More head bob as well as full body movement on a few zeds -No more secondary perk locked exp requirements. Perks now only gain a small bonus exp for doing those things. -You don't have to fight over exp as much compared to KF1. You only need to tag a zed to get exp so even if they are decapitated by a teammate. But exp is tied to perk weapons just like KF1 except for Survivalist where they can use any weapon to gain exp. EG: Berserkers using a magnum or deagle for crawlers will only get exp for gunslinger perk for those kills unless you had melee'd them somewhere before they die, then the exp will be split among them. -On top of perk bonuses, you get to choose an ability every 5 levels from 5-20. On a few classes, they're kind of useless though. -All classes spawn with a base weapon for their perk so you don't have to run around with just a pistol and knife. -Combined chainsaw with buzzsaw crossbow for berserkers. -Two different bosses to fight. They also take different amounts of damage depending on where you hit them: body/core, head, arms, and legs and what type of damage -Zeds can still fight each other although it doesn't happen as much it did in KF. -Gun butting/stab/thrust depending on what weapon you're holding at the moment so you can escape a clot's grasp when your gun runs out of rounds between mags, bash the head, to stumble a zed and get 1-2 seconds of breathing room or to save a teammate. -Sprinting. -Parry and block, all classes can only do this with a melee weapon (Eviscerator will allow you to block too). -Different grenades for classes.  Cons -Long start up time and depending on your computer, load in time too. -The knock down and stumbling have a cooldown still but they need to be built up to trigger now. -FPs rage function changed, they will rage after a certain time has gone by even if you're out of vision. -Leveling up does not grant discounts of on-perk weapons. -Kiting around the map does not work anymore up to a point, mobs will 'teleport/respawn' behind the closest corner if they can not see you, the team, or the team does not have vision of them minus stalker and Patriarch cloak. -Firebug burn no longer applies a -movement% to crisped zeds -Invisible walls still exist; only certain cars, boxes, rocks, and rails can be jumped on/over. -Background noise/music that isn't part of the music you can shut off. Atleast two maps has zeds in the background that will make noise so it might make things a little difficult for people that like to depend on hearing to play if they choose to hold out in those areas. -You can no longer outrun the bosses forever, they will catch up eventually even on perks with increased movement speed.

Look at my hours   The game has came a long way since its original release back in april of 2015. Tripwire HAS done things that the community is not proud of and has done things that seem rediculous at times, but what people tend to forget is that Tripwire tries their best to test new ideas. That was the main reason why the game launched into early access, to test new ideas and recieve community feedback.  The actual game is amazing. New weapons and perks have been added over the year and a half and each brings something unique. The weapons are ultra realistic being animated in over 200 fps so that the zed killing is made to give the most realistic weapon system on the market. Weapons range from melee weapons like a shovel for Berzerker to a high military grade electromagnetic rail gun for Sharpshooter. The maps are both Tripwire official and community made. There are about 12 maps to play from as of Novermber 18 (release day) and each have their own unique enviorment to cover in blood. And, tripwire have already announced another content update in about a month with a new weapon, new zed, and a new map (that's what's been confirmed so far but there may be more).  You can play from solo by yourself or grab a few friend or even random players and slaughter your way to victory to kill the patriarch or Hans volter. There are 4 difficulties; normal, hard, suicidal, and hell on earth. when you increase the difficulty, your enemies will not only have more health, they come in larger groups, dodge your attacks, run faster, and you earn less dosh (money). This sytem of difficulties makes the game feel more tactical as a shooter, instead of the enemies being sponges. Each perk has a specific role in the game such as slowing down enemies, crowd control, or just plain out taking out large zeds. Each perk as well has a specific set of weapons to play with, berzerker=melee, commando=assault rifles, support=shotguns, firebug=fire, Medic=medic weapons, demolitionist=explosives, gunslinger=heavy pistols, sharpshooter=rifles, SWAT=smg's, Survivalist= everything.  Tripwire releases a new mechanic/gamemode/patch (etc) and waits for feedback. If the community likes the new update, tripwire will keep that system and add similar systems like it. And if the community gives negitive feedback on the new system, They either fix it or completely remove it. For example, Tripwire decided to import a new system called resistance. It was ♥♥♥♥ing terrible. So, after community feedback, tripwire removed the system except large zed weaknesses. What the weeknesses are is that a Fleshpound is weaker to explosives but resistant to bullets and a Scrake is resistant to explosives but weak to bulllets. The reason why they kept those in particular is becuase it's what the community wanted, and the part that the community didn't want is taken away.  Now there is a flow of old players coming back to Killing Floor 2 because of its release and rather than looking in the past and giving good feedback, they're bashing on the things that are not done yet or on the situations with microtransactions. The reason why tripire doesn't remove microtransctions is because IT PAYS FOR FUTURE UPDATES. Tripwire has stated that right now, they are able to fund the game until the end of 2017 and that was half a year ago. These microtransactions are necessary for continuing free content updates instead of DLC. Some are even being rediculous in the fact that they are saying that 'TW is going to sell DLC now that the game is out.' The only time when they sell DLC is, and stated by tripwire theirselfs, 'We're not going to sell DLC unless the microtransaction system fails.' And don't worry, this isn't the Payday 2 type microtransactions where stats vary from weapon to weapon, it's just pretty skins with no real power other than to pimp your weapon.   I love this game to the death of me and i highly recommend this game to you and your friends.  9/10

Well, it's finally out of early access at least. It took a long time coming, and a few odd missteps with the microtransactions, but it's finally here.   The balance is right around where it should be, for hard and below. I can't comment on Suicidal or Hell On Earth as I don't play those. The weapons sound fantastic, and the gore system is a much-needed step up from the original. Performance isn't too shabby either. FXAA is still our only option for antialiasing, which is a problem. Still, it's an standalone update/new product for a game series that somewhat needed it.   All in all, it's not bad. Perhaps not the best due to a few minor kinks here and there, but a solid 8/10. After a few years of post-launch development, I fully expect this game to steal many, many more hours from me.

If you enjoy horde mode in other games (COD Zombie mode etc.) then Killing Floor 2 is a great pickup. Not only does it provide a unique challenge when playing alone, it gets progressivly harder when playing in groups. So long as Tripwire let the game take the route of the first KF, I believe the game will be as successful. The modding community for the first game was extensive, from maps, game modes, you name it. If that can be allowed to happen with the second game here, then I think this game will thrive as long as the first one has and continues to.    Cosmetics in this game are great for personality etc, but having the 'CSGO' crate and looting system is just unimaginative, and a quick way for the devs to grab a quick buck. I do however like the idea of using the Community Marketplace to buy and sell the cosmetics you find, and value being based on the total number of such items on the marketplace. All in all I don't hate the system I just think it could have been designed much better than an existing system in a different game.    Overall the game is well worth the money and has so much potential. With continued development I think it could be a game that last for many years.

So I saw Killing Floor 2 on Steam one day long ago, after long hours of Badwater and Upward in Tf2 (Pre matchmaking), and lucky me, It had a free weekend going for it. 'Cool,' my young brain thought,' a free trial!' After installing the game, I decided to adventure into a Solo suicidal, 7 wave game. My young brain thought myself a fairly decent fps gamer, and so I ventured in, unafraid...  And got my ♥♥♥ handed to me by a buffed up sawblades for arms fleshpound.  '♥♥♥♥ this unbalanced game' my brain said. Paired with the original lack of diversity in the classes, I didn't buy it immediatelya fter the free trial ran out.   And then a few weeks later, I saw the game again, with a bit more content. I told myself Id give it one more try. Normal, 4 waves, lets learn this game. And while Dr. Hans ended me with pathetic ease, I found I had enjoyed those 3 waves. So I tried multiplayer. Not only is the community a lot better than any other game Ive ever played, but the inherrent nature of the combining of perks showed what tf2 could have done with a better community. I kept the game, and continued to play. Although it had a few bumpy updates and glitches, (one of those glitches actually removed quite a bit of hours from the game for me, as I recieved all of my perks at level 25), the game continued to be interesting. Recently, each class and update theyve added has made the game better and better. I haven't even been to pvp yet, and this game has been one of my favs still. Ive never had a moment where Id ever want to return this game, or quit it, as the community, albethem competetive to a violent degree, the gore, the gameplay mechanics, and most suprisingly, the Zeds (this is one of few games with original ideas for their zombie like creatures, excluding the obvious uniformities in the genre such as bloats),are ever entertaining. With the recent beta showing a future shared weapons between perks, Reverend Alberts the Sharpshooter will win the west. If not the west, than hell itself.  So lets look at the actual game. When I bought the bundle, and because Id played KF2 before, thats the one I installed first. So In all truth, Im not a vet from KF1, and that does show a missing sight of information from my opinion of this game. But lets not look at it for the fact that its #2 in a series. Look at the game. Hop into a match on one of a growing variety of interesting maps (with the obligatory treasure hunt), and start World War Z(ed) with your chosen Character and Perk. Fun times. Honestly though, while I will admit the game does have room for improvement, the best I can do is basically spit ideas, as I have 0 clue on how to even come close to making a game. Concerning the ideas:  #1: more weapons and various buffs to random zed spawns based on difficulty/player count/current weapons of each player; Having 6 Beserkers will serve you fine for every zed that comes along....until an army and a fleshpound show up with melee resistance and attacks that slow/cant be parried. That being said, Some of the new weapons are more or less effected by these random effects, allowing for a different weapon choice in every game, out of a much longer list than what we have now.  #2: and they're doing this now, shared weapon perks. Gunslinger revolvers with the Sharpshooter perks, Sharpshooter rifles with the Gunslinger perks, spread the love of weapons.  #3: We don't need 6 Alberts, although he is the coolest character. Let the players build their own avatars, and while we're at it, within the basic constraints of the perks, give the player more than just 2 choices per level.  #4: Don't go the random gambler way. All thats useful for is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ off your community and earning gambling based microtransaction money. Add the skins to the shop, .50$ for battle scarred normal, up to a max of, idk, 5 maybe 10 for the factory new master crafted. Let the players choice determine their progression in game and what they really want to buy. #5: and again, they're doing this now, more and scarier zeds. Fleshpounds, Scrakes, and Mobs, aswell as the occasional Patriarch missle or Hans grenade spam, are the main things that kill people on the floor. More demi-bosses, like the new Gorefiend and similar ideas, if you please, tripwire #6: If we're adding new modes, for those people who really hate the community or want more in th franchise, a story/adventure mode for free unlockable crates (free drop, free to open) that may contain weapon skins sell-able back to the market or over the steam market, cosmetics, or various other oddities.  #7: The big one: More than 2 bosses. Hans is very innovative in his design. Patty is terrifying. Lets see more! Maybe, Idk, a 4 armed fleshpound? How about a bloat-and-husk fusion?   Anyone else, if you want to, put the ideas below, and (I hate to ask) rate this so that people who DON'T scroll through random comments see this, and eventually with any luck, someone from Tripwire will see this, pass it up the chain, and maybe just maybe we'll see some of the communities ideals behind the game.

It is really interesting that alot of negative reviews here are negative not because the game is BAD, but rather because it's not what they expected and/or it was managed poorly. Reminds me of Battleborn, Watch Dogs and Shadow Warrior.   I certainly got my money's worth out of this game already (mostly playing it in soloQ), however I usually play 2 - 3 games at a time and then do something else. When played in short sessions, the game is fantastic and tons of fun. Random spawning (and greater variety) of big zeds would help make each game different, but isn't crucial. I genuinely enjoyed it.  On the other hand, it appears that if you play it in longer sessions and frequently, the game becomes monotonous and boring (not for me, i'm judging by other's reviews) so keep that in mind.  TL;DR It's great to rest and have some fun regularly, but can become monotonous during longer sessions (never happened to me personally, but that's what people say).

In KIlling Floor 2, you got 8+2 upcoming perks, specializing in different weaponry and playstyle, to overcome the increasingly bigger waves of zeds. Scrakes and FPs are the main threats, as they hit hard, and have HP. Boss wave is ' run around the map looking for ammo, and pew-pew'  We got a sprint button, no longer run faster with the knife out.2 new zeds, cyst: low-clot, slasher:aggro clot. New boss, hans, armed with machineguns, gas,and a third boss is coming up, the matriarch (right?) we also got a lot of customization options, crates, the trading floor, no stat boosts, just skins.  Clot & clot variants, easy targets, just watch out for their grab, as it forces you to aim at them and you get stuck until the zed is bashed or killed. Gorefasts, them jawless brothaflippas, usually run to slice you with their long thingie, avoid that, maybe? Crawlers die from a prod, but they look nasty, and... crawl?Mr. Holmes, you are wonderful! Aim lower! they come in groups, from vents and other narrow places. Stalkers, kinda invisible, female, clothes = no, but she's not in the mood... but no worries, she gunna roundhouse kick your face off. Bloats are fat, shoot their heads, body has hp for days.They look after you, barf on you to keep ya warm. Sirens scream, RIP headphone users. Husks usually fireball you, or suicide, or BBQ the whole squad with a flamethrower, coz why not. Scrake carries a chainsaw as he is a lumberjack, rages when he is below 50% hp, which means he runs and attacks you like a big angry guy with a chainsaw. Fleshpounds used to be kindergarten tutors, until some construction workers thought it would be fun to replace their arms with drills, and add a rage-o-meter to their chest, along with other neat KKona changes. Now, everyone looks like a construction worker to them, and they want to take revenge. No hard feelings, rite?Shhhh, hug it out...  Question: how to win as humans in Versus? getting to the bossfight is no problem, but winning... my first 2 vs matches, patty killed us, we killed them before bosswave. now, 3rd game, i got patty role for the first time, was playing ranged mode, then a teammate said melee is 2hit, but one of them survived, and kited me till I died. Now I know what the the other guy wanted from me in my second vs as human, when he said, 'kite in the farmhouse'.I was like, OK, gotta fire tons of bullets, find lot of ammo boxes,and run. Nope, just run 24/7 and close the doors you pass,no need to damage the patty yourself, because if you dont deal damage as the patty, control of the patty is not given to a teammate (like tank l4d style), you take damage over time.Thought I could catch up.Rekt in pasta.#themoreyouknow.  So, in the next VS match, we tried holding the prison courtyard vs boss, it failed, but, armed with the kiting 'knowledge', I did it! It felt pretty bad though, lvl25 medic running, using corners to avoid pat line of sight, healing every time I got hit, (I didnt look behind me, at all). So yeah, cheesy tactic. Problem is, I dont know how to beat boss with actually the squad dealing all damage , not this kiting stuff, coz boss just gotta rush in melee into the squad, killing all high-damage dealers, whose movement speed is not buffed, and its over.

Seeing how Tripwire interactive have been dishing out free weekends like there's no tomorrow so you've probably experienced this game a little.  If not (or you couldn't be bothered) then this is your lucky day for me to personally indulge you in the features of this game.   First off I wanna say that this game has been getting a bad rap for micro transactions that are NON - COMPULSORY so it is not a pay to win game. Any new weapons that have been bought by one person can be shared via the trader and KF2's drop system allows you to recieve crates and cosmetics (yay c:) by ending a match either by dying or winning. ( No weapon skins so far though :c) Most of the skins and cosmetics are created by the COMMUNITY so people dissing this game for microtransactions are huge hypocrites. The people that complain about the core elements of the gameplay (you know the actual stuff) are Killing Floor veterans that aren't satisfied it isn't exactly like the original game. Custom servers are available for KF veterans which offer the old maps and level system but still keep the update characters and mobs.  Now for the nitty gritty. If you didn't already know, the killing floor franchise started out as an unreal tournament mod (allegedly) and was developed into a british zombie killing wave survival style game in which the aim was to defeat the Patriarch at the end of any chosen map. Bad news for you the Patriarch survived and his hordes of 'Zeds' have marched across Europe, ransacking and ravaging the landscape with the remains of their victims.  The new game features an updated version of the Patriarch aka 'Patty' (which looks a lot more boss like than the original in my opinion) and a 100 year old German man named Hans Volter who keeps himself functioning with Horzine biomass (Nicknamed 'The Nazi'). Currently there are 7 classes(3 more to come!) to play from along with a number of different characters which include some of the original killing floor characters such as Briar and Foster. Each 'Perk' has 4 weapons and from what I have deduced, each weapon is part of a tier from 1-4 so one weapon for each tier, including special grenades, perk bonuses and knives!  The game so far is pretty balanced with the odd buff required here and there (Demolitions seriously needs more perk bonuses, seriously 3 compared to 4, 5 and 6?!) as well as the odd nerf (Hans' melee and hp, it's more than the the patriarch...).  The maps are virtual eye candy and each one is pretty large except for Biotics Lab and Farm House but have been balanced with large amounts of flat ground for you to easily rack up headshots with.  Do note that there are some exploits that come with this game that TWI have not fixed yet such as the farmhouse bush (Not the first one, the other one) which people are quite divided by at the moment.  Gameplay wise, a vast improvement from the original killing floor with the addition of the sprint and bash button as opposed to moving faster with your knife (which made no sense when carry a heavy weapon such as the M99 AMR or the LAW in the original game). I also like the M.E.A.T. system which gives you the ability to blast bits off of the chosen body part of a zed which was in the first game but only featured 5 places whereas KF2 features 5 for the head alone and reports from the developers say there are as many as 26 different fragments of a zed you can separate from them along with the fluids and guts option which makes for extreme zombie killing (zombie blood fountains galore).   Speaking of extreme Zombie killing (They're not actually zombies, they're failed experiments to create super soldiers) they added a badass soundtrack of heavy metal songs from artists such as Demon Hunter and Rocky Gray to make you feel like you're the bees knees when destroying the face of someone that used to be normal before they signed their life away to be experimented upon.  The difficulty ramp up system is a work of genius and not only does it take into account the setting you've chosen but it also multiplies key values such as zed numbers and health by the number of players on the team (up to 6 on standard servers.)  The first game featured an objective mode which saw you carrying out instructions set by a certain character. This was really enjoyable and broke away from the tedium of the killing floor mode in order to appeal to players who got bored of the game quite quickly. I would like to see this in the new game as well as a few other ideas ( I thoroughly enjoyed playing a custom gamemode which was similar to a game I think was called 'Dread' in which you had to find keys to escape with teammates while avoiding a reskinned invulnerable fleshpound who had very poor vision in the dark.)  This game already feels finished even though it been early access for quite a few month now (like 8 or something). They really should think about streching out the updates instead of packaging a big batch of content into one update then leaving it for inumerable months for people to get bored of within a few weeks. By adding small amount of new features every 2 or 3 months they can ensure people remain interested (*Cough* Q!) which is similar to what Valve do with Team Fortress 2.  A gripe I do have with this game is that my frames do drop suddenly for no reason. It's not anything to do with my computer because sometimes it runs perfectly fine and I'm able to play full matches with out any hiccups. I run every setting on max and most of the time it's as smooth as silk. Times where it drops are usually when I open the steam overlay to reply to any banter that has been thrown downwind of me and usually it's when I just start up the game. I suspect it's something to do with texturing failures and poor optimization to steam but eh.  Zed time is a feature which has crossed over from the original game but has been beefed up tremendously. At level 25 with any perk, you unlock powerful skills which can only be activated during zed time but can be extremely useful even during these random events.  Apparently there are problems with matchmaking but I don't use that mode, I just play on any HoE match as long as it has 'playas' if you know what I mean. The game's difficulties are as follows; Normal, Hard, Suicidal, Hell on Earth. Normal increases the amount of time you have at the trader and halves the damage and health of each zed whereas in hard onwards the recieve damage ramp ups of up to 1.75 and a static value of x1.0 health at hard onwards (excluding large zeds/bosses) as well as a larger number of zeds.   I would like to see a boss for each map which allows you to strategize more than the random system it has more and if some people don't like that idea, a 'Randomizer' mode could be implemented to mix things up a little. I would also like to see zeds which have been affected by the environment such as zeds with frozen/frost bitten arms in outpost and protruding twigs and scars in black forest to add realism.(Larger variety of zeds)  The voice acting is pretty bad for the most part, the only believeable characters are Ana, Foster, Hayato, and Briar so I would like some improvements to be done there as well as a wider variety of characters later on (a lot of people are asking for more female characters - the randy buggers - but I would like to see cyborgs and robots most of all.)  Most people who play the game have a great idea of teamwork and stick together but don't bother to read about resistances and weaknesses of the zeds so you'll find people trying to blow up a scrake with a 50% explosive resistance sometimes. Strategies to complete harder difficulties usually involve a medic, a beserker and a place to camp but I have found that zooming across the map in a tightly knit group actually works better and gives you a chance to enjoy the scenery.  As it stands I would give this game an 8/10  TL;DR : Kill urself

So the game is out of EA and I'm still playing. Yes I hate the microtransactions, yes Survivalist is a cop out class and I'm unhappy that we didn't get new weapons for it. The game still runs well, the other 9 classes are fun to play and the community is decent. Worth a buy.  Edit: The recent content added is pretty awesome. Firebug is my new favorite class, and the two maps are nice to look at and brutal to play. Catacombs gets dark after a few round with Sirens nades and stray bullets taking out the few light sources. Evacuation is interesting with all the elevation changes, it's a large map and offers lots of places to hold out. Game plays great as always, the changes to the Zerk make it the perfect tank and the Zwei is simply fun to swing around. I complained a bit in my last update and I should have had more faith. Buy this game.  Tripwire has renewed my faith in Early Access. The game is not nearly complete at this point and yet it still plays smooth and fast. Graphics look damn good, no fps drops on my end with a R9 270 card and 8 core processor. The guns feel great, they hit hard and feel great. Zeds look great, blow apart in interesting ways, the crawler even crunches when you shoot/smash/cut it like it should. Voice acting is solid, i like how my character responds to what's going on. Cuts down on typing SC and FP and gun here all the time. Only 4 perks and three maps as of yet but it plays great and you get a good mix of skins and customization to start, this is a good buy.

After playing this game for a reasonable amount of time, I've got to say that this game is even better than Killing Floor 1.  First of, you get a new start-weapon for each perk and new perk abilities which you can choose from once you reach perk lv 5 (lv 25 is max perk lv), the sirens crawlers and stalkers are still annoying af, the Fleshpound looks even more frightening with its size and attacks same as for the Scrake. Zed time or slowmotion time is still awesome, the gore is perfect and brutal and when you add in some friends which got skins looking like Mr Foster or Dj Scully you just know that you're going to have a good old KF time. and the small details added by the developers make this game so unique, such as when you play as a Berserker and you got a bloody Katana from slayign too many Zeds, when you press R, your character swings the Katana a little bit to the ground so that the blood from the Katana falls of, leaving a small puddle of blood on the ground. I would reconmend this game to all my friends, the graphics are good, the zed killing is fun and overall KF2 is one of my favourite games till this day.  Last but not least, a Killing Floor pun:   What do you call a Fleshpound from the hood?  A freshpound.  I am so sorry, I'll let myself out.  Peace.

I really wish the scoring system on Steam would be a bit more complex than yay or nay. On one hand, I like KF2, on the other, I don't see it in enough regard to recommend it to everybody.  It's the same KF you know and loved, if you knew and loved KF, and of course that's great. The original was already a fun-fest of intense corridor shooting and boss battles you could grind your teeth through. In many aspects, it has kept that appeal. But it's also the same KF. Monsters are almost all the same as in previous games (they said they'd add more), weapons the same (likewise), but at this moment in time it feels more like a HD remastering than an actual new game.  But the maps are new. Sure, some of them are heavily inspired from classics, but even so they feel fresh and large and interesting to explore (they even added secrets on each map that you can find (you get an achievement. yaaaay). Also new to the map design is the large areas and rooms, adding something new, but also substracting some of the use of barricades. The claustrophobic maps are fewer and even those are usually half-n-half. On higher difficulty levels it might be worth it, but on Normal it's almost pointless and it will only slow your insaciable hunger for splattering zombie brains.  There are two things, however, that really stick out of the pudding pie like the toe of a dirty hobo who tripped and went smack-right in it.  First of, the game is head-to-butt filled with achievements, the lazy kind too. Beat this map on normal, beat it on hard, beat it on suicidal, beating on omg srsly u guys. Beat the other 10-15 maps 4 times. Kill 50 x enemies with y class, kill 100. You get the idea. If anything, they feel like a grind from an MMO but without the reward it, to me, more like a way to torment completionists than make your game special.  And then there's the microtransactions for the esthetic items. Which are BORDERLINE decent, since the game only costs 20 quid. Even so, 2.49 for a key to unlock a chest that has a chance of dropping one in 11 types of items? At the other pole, you do ocassionally get drops from ending levels, but they feel rare and random and not very special. So far I got 3 drops in 7 hours, 2 of which are common and one is a box.  I can't hold too much of a grudge, since Tripwire seem like decent fellas, adding new stup and supporting their games years ahead of other mainstream publishers, and the microtransactions only seem to be a way to keep the studio afloat, and I'm positive that in time they will add new and interesting features. For now it's more of the same. Thake that as you will.

Ah, good old Killing Floor with new textures, new sounds, new maps ! I can feel myself alive again when i get home after work. Life is beautiful...again.  POSITIVES: +It's back! It's with us! It kicks asses! We were waiting for it, and here it is!  +IT HAS GRAPHICS! Yup! It's gorgeous now! You can bash someone's head with a hammer and observe the beauty: all the ketchup, arms, legs, teeth and whatnot ! No ears though! Monsters dont have any... Need ears!  +IT... already had sounds, BUT! Now they're more... juicy? Yes, i guess so. You can add some bass to it and listen to that music! Oh, that music! Music makes things more... thrilling? Yes, i guess so. Yeeeees those screams and blood, and... but i digress. Music, sounds, yes, good !  +IT HAS MORE PERKS ! Yes, yes, It has! We always want more of... something... whatever - then why not perks? More freedom of choice is always a good thing, donchathink? More freedom of choice to decide if you wanna be a berserker or... a black guy (Mafia3)  NEGATIVES? Let me think...  -Monsters! Monsters, yes. Almost every evil creature there (including me) is from the first Killing Floor. Sure they look fresh... and smell, but nothing really new about them... aside from look and smell.  -Maps! You see: when you kill something, you need to feel that new setting around you. Something romantic maybe? Well, maybe not... After you make a few rounds in that map, this map WILL be like a breath of fresh air, but when some... f... sonof... (though im pretty sure his name was Roger) vote for that previous map you've played, and every other... ROGER vote for that map with him (because there is not much to choose really), you will quit and go to another server.  -Field of view! I CANT SEE MAH LEEEGS !...Ahem... what i meant was: you cant set your fov to 90 or less. Only through console. It will always feel like you're using a scope or something. Everything is zoomed. Blood everywhere... those screams...errr where was i? Ah, yes!  -Game modes! Yes, ofcourse, you can shoot and crush things here (ooh i love crushing), but eventually you will feel that need, that urge to do something else! Along with shooting and crushing. Like making pancakes with raspberry jam, YUM! (only for yourself ofcourse. Sure you can add some teamplay to it and make YOUR MINIONS to make pancakes with raspberry jam for you, YUM!)  And that's it, see? Everything is still there, it just has some new features, new additions. A good sequel of that game we always remembered and loved. I Recommend  Almost forgot! Main feature of this game: You can retex and redesign everything ingame! Right in the middle of a fight! Dont like the looks of that item? No problem! Just let some clot to follow you to that item you dont like and 'retex' it with a single strike to the clot. We all know that song: 'If you dont like it then you shoulda PUT SOME BLOOD ON IT! Wuh uh oh uh uh...'

My updated review since it has just been released and I have to say its still up there with one of my favorite games at the moment. Yeah it got a lot of hate because of in game cosmetic things to buy but c'mon who gives a ♥♥♥♥ if somebody wants to change the way they look, does not give them any advantage at all so I'm not really fussed about it. My favorite things about the game include the awesome music, gun animations and sounds are really well done, graphics are superb and really well optimized so the game itself runs a treat. Plenty of maps that are very detailed with plenty of different environments. Good friendly community which is needed in a team based game. Steam workshop with loads of stuff in it making some cool modded servers. Vs mode where you can play as the zeds is also very cool. 4 difficulty levels making sure your always challenged. Now things I do not like about the game so much. Low level players going into high difficulty servers and instantly dying as a result wasting the space of someone decent that can help the team better although the team can kick them if they wish. Leveling up perks can take ages, I reckon just over 300 hours needed to level up all 10 perks playing it normally and new content updates are quite slow coming but when we do get them they are usually quite good and you can tell from the quality they take there time with things and are not rushing. All in all I'm happy with how the whole early access went so gg tripwire for that and I cannot wait for more content in the future :-)

First off, I want to say I also don't NOT recommend this game. I actually think it would be really fun if not for one REALLY mindblowingly annoying feature. The 'monsters behind your back' feature. This game, without exception, will make monsters be behind you when you turn around. It doesn't matter if you have your back to a wall, monsters will manage to spawn between you and the wall. Or if you clear a section of hallway then turn to deal with the monsters attacking you from behind for even a second, new monsters will be RIGHT THERE atacking you.   It makes it very hard to learn the game and very hard to play solo; which is how you get good enough to really enjoy playing the game. I've had luck on only one map the 'farmhouse' map, at keeping things from being suddenly behind me, and that's only because of all the open space. At any other time, the game will trap you against a wall, surround you with monsters and kill you.  This is absolutely an angry rant, as I like everything else about this game, and if I could actually maneuver some, it'd be even more enjoyable. The absence of the ability to run or to jump very high also kinda limits this. I mean, if it were you in tese situations, don't you think running would be one of your first priorities? How high could *you* jump if some ravening mutant was trying to eat your legs? Even if it had some kind of stamina bar, being able to run would make more sense. Add to that the fact that none of the monsters have any problem running...  Overall, I think this is a fun game. I like testing myself against it. ...but I also keep wanting to throw my laptop across the room when I try to escape a zombie, only to be unable to move even the same speed it does, or to watch as my 'professional' struggles to reload, or to fire my gun for what feels like a second then have to watch as I try to reload again, or to be backing slowly from a mob of zombies I have completely under control, only to take 5 steps and run into an entire horde of them that wasn't there two seconds ago.  For those of you thinking 'well, you're supposed to play this in a team', I never feel right trying to join a team as a painfully unskilled noob and bringing everyone I'm playing with down... and yet trying to learn this game is making it seem like all I can do is die a million times over before I'm 'good' enough to play with other people. After playing a game a million times only to lose just about the same number of times, how much do *you* want to play it more?  Lastly, I want to say this review might change. I'll get better (hopefully). Right now, I'm getting gang ♥♥♥♥♥ against the wall over and over by magic zombies who can appear out of thin air. Contrary to what the developers think, this is NOT FUN.
