Finally launced and its glorious! If you love FPS online this is something you can't miss. The graphics will strain your system, be forewarned, but its does scale fairly well. All i can say after playing it for hundreds of hours since launch,is I want more! More maps, more enemies, more modes (one can hope). Very solid game experience. Scroll down for earlier thoughts...      Pretty good balance in games. Still takes FOREVER to launch on my hardware. No idea why, all other 2016 games launch in a pinch, so I'm guessing it IS KF2's fault. Hopefully, they will issue new launch code when it finally releases. stil, i don't know how many long term players will keep sticking with it. I have noticed a definately drop off in experienced players. Seems not quite dead in between new perk launches, but definately taking a snooze.  EDIT: KF2 may (read will) add microtransactions. For those of you that consider this an issue, please be aware.  This is a review of the pre-launch version sold on April 21, 2015. Will update if anything major changes.  8.5/10 Buy recommendation as of this writing.   The game is fun and well worth the low price. It currently has only 3 maps, but it is probably safe to assume more will be added in the future. Plays very similar to KF1, but with up dates, graphical mainly. So, this review is primarily intended for people who did not play the first. Odds are if you played the first one, you were itching to buy the sequel. If you never tried it before, do yourself a favor and try the first one to see if you like it. Basically co-op zombie killing waves with minimal story.  Some people have been reporting problems running the game in the forums. I did not encounter any problems whatsoever, so I can't speak to that. The game ran a little slow on launch day, not sure why, but the day after and subsequent it ran fine on my 3 year old hardware (i7 and sli 680s). i do have to say it ran my systems a little hot, with my water-cooled loop being noticeably warm to the touch.  The game itself it an update all around, with the maps being absolutely stunning, multi-level affairs. Fun in the long term, may be a little confusing to noobs. They looked great even on non-top level settings. Lots of nifty clutter make the maps seem more realistic, monster animations are great as are textures all around. Lively EDM music and good use of dimensional surround.  The game could perhaps use a little tweaking here and there in terms of balancing, but overall I would say its completely release ready at this point. I did not run into anything that stopped me from enjoying the product.  Killing Floor definately picked up L4D's crown.   Update 24 Sept/15: okie, so demo (my fav class from KF1) and pyro released, along with a bunch of new maps and some major balancing. Love the new classes, new maps are good as well. Catacombs is VERY dark. Balancing has somewhat broken the game. The end boss (and some FPs) are now virtually impossible to kill on higher difficulty levels, unless THE WHOLE TEAM WORKS TOGETHER AND KNOW WHAT THEY ARE DOING!!! But it runs buttery smooth on max settings with my Titan X!   Update: glitched on Biolab, floated above the floor for a few minutes until it fixed itself Update: have trouble connecting to some servers..the animation just keeps playing endlessly Update: definately hiting a content-wall, what I mean, running out of fun factor. Mind you, the game is still worth the price of admission, but I hope they add more 'stuff' at release. the maps are getting boring and the player pool is shrinking, with only a few noobs and the grinders remaining.

TL;DR: Killing zeds in itself is incredibly fun, and the game has the potential to become great as both a sequel and a standalone title. However, it is in the hands of a dev team that has made it obvious to their community that they care more about financial gain than the wellbeing of the game and its players. And let's be real here, 'Early Access Done Right' is a statement that contradicts itself.  Pros:  -Nice UI -Lots of graphics options -Lots of audio options, including the ability to minimize banter of player characters and enable vocals on the soundtrack -Separate adjustments for mouse sensitivity while in and out of ADS, as well as full-on keybinding -Many gameplay adjustment options including adjustable gore intensity, adjustable FOV, adjustable friendly HUD size, and the ability to enable/disable crosshairs, weapon quick select, zed kill ticker, boss health bar, welder visibility in inventory, alt pistol aim, auto-turn on clot grab, high pitch noise, and anti motion sickness -Each character has their own voice, unlike in KF1 where there was an absurdly huge selection of characters and only a handful of voice actors across all of them -Character customization -Better perk selection and customization than KF1, and leveling is actually fun rather than tedious -Optional tutorial for beginners -Suprisingly fun solo mode (which is probably where I've clocked the bulk of my hours in this game) -Hectic and fun online co-op play -Good visuals -Weapons feel heavy and powerful -Addition of a bash feature that makes it easier to keep zeds off you and break glass without having to needlessly waste ammo or take time to switch to a melee weapon -Zed types are easy to distinguish from each other -Exceptional dynamic gore system that includes permenant blood spillage as well as optional implementation of Physx Flex, which adds dynamic soft-body organs and actual 3D blood and bile to the gore -Interesting new take on welding, wherein the doors have health bars in addition to weld integrity. Thus, fully welded doors can be easily broken down if the door itself is damaged enough. Instead of respawning on their own after each wave, players using the Support perk have to manually rebuild doors that have been broken down if players want to use them again -Multiple bosses, including the Patriarch from the first game (who has gotten a pretty heavy design overhaul. I much prefer the new Patriarch design, but there are plenty of people who disagree with me) -High replay value regardless of its inherently repetitive gameplay -Mod workshop implementation -Good and sometimes exceptional user-made content -Addition of a live update system that allows the devs to make gameplay tweaks without having to constantly ship hefty updates for the game -Delivers better on the sheer joy of killing zombies than any other zombie game I've ever played  Cons:  -While the dynamic gore system in the game is great, the Physx Flex feature is exclusive to computers with Nvidia chipsets and comes across as a trial by fire for PC hardware at best, and a tacked-on (albiet mildly amusing) gimmick at worst -Tacked-on gamepad support -Implementation of a crate and key economy and Steam Marketplace integration that is controversial on its own, but was also added not long after the gaming community blew up at Overkill for doing the exact same thing with PayDay 2. Oh, and I should also mention that the game wasn't even finished when they implemented it -Only two female characters -Martial Artist perk not included in full release -Survivalist perk was obviously thrown together to meet Tripwire's ten-perk promise by the time the game left early access, and said perk is still only available in the preview build -The leap in difficulty between difficulty settings is jarring to say the least -Melee is not nearly as satisfying as it should be -Watered-down quick chat system -Implementation of a half-baked VS mode that damages Killing Floor's reputaion as one of the most prominent and well-recieved co-op titles in the PC gaming community -Other technical problems as a result of being an unfinished game, regardless of the fact that it is now out of early access -Censoring and banning of people on forums simply because Tripwire didn't like what people had to say  I will add and remove items on these lists if things get changed, or if I simply remember something I forgot to address.

this is more of a brief overview than anything else.  Killing Floor 2 is a CO-OP survival horror game where you fight off waves of zeds, (basically an army of clones) to earn DO$H from killing zeds,healing, etc.. , between each wave you are given the opportunity to upgrade your gear for better equipment and better weapons with improved firepower, rinse and repeat until the end of the final wave where you then fight a boss a to beat the round, currently there are multiple bosses with 1 randomly chosen for the boss fight,atleast 4 weapons per class (hopefully more down the road).   Aside from the lack of content in in early access, its probably the best early access purchase i've made considering the mess of certain other games, which in my opinion have been in early access for far too long and have seen too little content promised VS actually implemented. Now on release, the game finally has the amount of content i'd expect from a game fresh out of early access , and is slowly and surely becoming superior to KF1, its as if KF1 had a graphical overhaul to bring it in line with today's standards with some tweaks and updates such as the addition of sprinting and weapon bashing.  I have had no problems with stability or optimisation and overall runs solidly without any graphical glitches. (however FLEX does cause some frame drops occasionally during heavy combat)  given the way TW distributed content in KF1 with the majority of dlc being as character packs (purely cosmetic) and weapon skins(again mostly cosmetic) with free content updates (maps,weapons,some free chracters,etc..) Additionally the SDK being available practically from release in early access means there are many mods/maps already out there on the steam workshop for you to download if you get bored with just the stock maps or create your own if you feel up to the task.  combat: combat is brutal and gory with explosions fragmenting the zeds into chunks of flesh,organs and blood (depends on much you want) that redecorate the interior of the maps as you progress through wave after wave of zeds. Also,you can tweak how much blood and gore you actually want in the options and config files.  the weapons sounds are pretty good and sound quite weighty and are satisfying to use, mostly the classes are reasonably balanced (some areas do need a bit of attention but overall the main classes seem to be ok)  The attention to detail is also really well thought out especially in the weapon animation (eg. you can see the bits wobble in slow mo while firing due to the frame rate at which the animation has been designed around(the frame rate for the weapons is something like 220 fps so they can fit in more detail into the animation))  For example you can press reload with a full magazine for some nicely animated bits of gun checking/fiddling, given these dont actually affect anything within the game its a nice touch of polish to the game.  melee is also very satisfying, especially with the zerker weapons for slicing through zeds like butter.  microtransactions: you can take them or leave them, the microtrasactions are purely cosmetic, so far, at least anyway. this means you dont actually have to spend any money on them if you dont want to, however this does seem to be the replacment for skins/characters as dlc, which generally help fund more FREE content updates for the community.  overall summary: the trailers for KF2 basically sum up the gameplay in a nutshell, so if you really cant decide whether its your type of gameplay, watch them,if you dont like the look of the game froom the trailers, its probably not a game you want. (best to do some looking around at gameplay really)  hopefully they continue the crazy events like the summer sideshow etc.. from KF1  If TW keep going in the direction they are heading in it will hopefully turn out as a solid game all the way down the road. would solidly reccomend as a wave based shooter even when not on sale  Pros: +TW normally deliver nearly all major content for FREE(maps,new zeds,most new weapons,etc...) +good amount of content +satisfying gunplay +gore is well done +actually requires teamplay on the higher difficulties to succeed +new soundtrack +now has sprinting +bash feature +random bosses  Cons -probably want some friends to play this with on higher difficulties, as while solo is fun, multiplayer really is the proper experience and team coordination is a MUST on higher difficulty levels. -physx can be very intensive so you'd better have a good gpu to handle it on higher settings, worth it though.   Currently in it's current state available for purchase i would rate:   8/10 - Not for The Squeamish.     Will upate this review if anything changes
If unlike me, you have friends then it's a pretty fun game :^)

TL;DR: A much better game now that it got released.  When I was playing Killing Floor 2, I thought there was a disaster on Tripwire's hands. Balancing issues plagued the game severely in Early Access and I noticed it was way to different from the original game. But is that necesacarily a bad thing now that I think about it?  No. It's not.  This game is good for what's it's for. Now that it has been released, the balancing issues are gone and I felt the gameplay was much better now that I have gotten my chance to play this again.  Don't listen to people ♥♥♥♥♥ about microtransactions. Don't want to spend a lot of money on skins? DON'T F-ING DO IT THEN. Or spend as much as you please! I don't care! Microtransactions are not necesscarily bad if they are used good. Team Fortress 2 has a bunch of microtransactions and you can use them if you want. Alhtough buying keys in TF2 is much more like gambling. I use microtransactions sometimes and I don't think it's bad all the time!  Anyways. Short and sweet, the game works now that it's released. I am impressed that Tripwire listened to the fans and did everything right. I still like Killing Floor 1 better, but this is a good entry.
